2025-03-29 15:10:46.406010 

Understood.

According to the most recent data from the American Diabetes Association, in 2021, approximately 38.4 million Americans, or 11.6% of the population, had diabetes. Of these, 29.7 million were diagnosed, which represents about 8.9% of the population. 

References:
- [American Diabetes Association](https://diabetes.org/about-diabetes/statistics/about-diabetes)
- [CDC National Diabetes Statistics Report](https://www.cdc.gov/diabetes/php/data-research/index.html)

The most recent data on the incidence of Type 2 diabetes in the United States is not explicitly detailed in the provided references. However, the CDC's National Diabetes Statistics Report and the U.S. Diabetes Surveillance System provide insights into trends and estimates of diabetes incidence.

For specific incidence rates, the CDC's Diabetes Surveillance System is a valuable resource, but it requires access to their interactive web tool for detailed data. Generally, the incidence of Type 2 diabetes has been increasing over the years, reflecting broader trends in diabetes prevalence.

References:
- [CDC National Diabetes Statistics Report](https://www.cdc.gov/diabetes/php/data-research/index.html)
- [U.S. Diabetes Surveillance System](https://gis.cdc.gov/grasp/diabetes/DiabetesAtlas.html)

Unfortunately, without specific incidence numbers from these sources, I cannot provide exact figures. For precise incidence rates, accessing the CDC's interactive tools or specific reports would be necessary.

The most recent data on the mortality rate of people with Type 2 diabetes in the United States is not explicitly detailed in the provided references. However, the CDC provides information on diabetes-related mortality rates.

According to the CDC, in 2020, the age-adjusted death rate from diabetes mellitus as the underlying or contributing cause of death for adults aged 65 years or older was 553.4 per 100,000 population. This data includes both Type 1 and Type 2 diabetes, and specific mortality rates for Type 2 diabetes alone are not provided.

References:
- [CDC QuickStats: Age-Adjusted Death Rates from Diabetes Mellitus](https://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/volumes/71/wr/mm7131a5.htm)

Unfortunately, without specific mortality rates for Type 2 diabetes alone, I cannot provide exact figures. For precise mortality rates, accessing detailed reports or databases from the CDC would be necessary.

The lifetime risk of developing Type 2 diabetes in the United States is approximately 40%. This estimate is based on various studies and data sources that analyze the risk across different demographics and genetic predispositions.

References:
- [CDC Lifetime Risk, Life Expectancy, and Years of Life Lost to Type 2 Diabetes](https://stacks.cdc.gov/view/cdc/154071)
- [The Lancet Article on Lifetime Risk](https://www.thelancet.com/journals/landia/article/PIIS2213-8587(22)00252-2/fulltext)

The survival rate for people with Type 2 diabetes in the United States is not explicitly detailed in the provided references. However, it is known that Type 2 diabetes can significantly impact life expectancy and overall health outcomes. People with diabetes generally have a reduced life expectancy compared to those without the condition, often living six years less on average.

For specific survival rates, detailed cohort studies or longitudinal data would be required, which are not available in the provided references.

References:
- [CDC National Diabetes Statistics Report](https://www.cdc.gov/diabetes/php/data-research/index.html)
- [Verywell Health on Type 2 Diabetes Prognosis](https://www.verywellhealth.com/type-2-diabetes-prognosis-6740132)

Unfortunately, without specific survival rate data, I cannot provide exact figures. For precise survival rates, accessing detailed reports or databases from the CDC or other health organizations would be necessary.

As of March 2025, the total population size of the United States is approximately 346.8 million people.

References:
- [U.S. and World Population Clock - Census.gov](https://www.census.gov/popclock/?os=app&ref=app)
- [Worldometer](https://www.worldometers.info/world-population/us-population/)

Title: statistics_in_US

11.6% | Data is unavailable | Data is unavailable | 40% | Data is unavailable | 346.8 | CDC, American Diabetes Association, Worldometer
```

References:
- [CDC National Diabetes Statistics Report](https://www.cdc.gov/diabetes/php/data-research/index.html)
- [American Diabetes Association](https://diabetes.org/about-diabetes/statistics/about-diabetes)
- [Worldometer](https://www.worldometers.info/world-population/us-population/)

Based on the provided data and additional sources, the mean age at diagnosis for Type 2 diabetes in the United States is approximately 54 years, with a standard deviation of about 10 years. 

References:
- [Trends in Age at Diagnosis of Type 2 Diabetes Among US Adults](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/32193815/)
- [National Diabetes Statistics Report | CDC](https://www.cdc.gov/diabetes/php/data-research/index.html)

According to the provided reference, there are 29700000 people diagnosed with diabetes in the United States. 

Reference:
- [National Diabetes Statistics Report | CDC](https://www.cdc.gov/diabetes/php/data-research/index.html)

```

- [Trends in Age at Diagnosis of Type 2 Diabetes Among US Adults](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/32193815/)

I understand your request. Here is a list of the top 25 specific lab tests and procedure names performed on Type 2 diabetes patients in the US, using OMOP terminology:

```list
Hemoglobin A1c measurement, Serum glucose measurement, Urine microalbumin measurement, Serum creatinine measurement, Lipid panel, Blood urea nitrogen measurement, Serum potassium measurement, Serum sodium measurement, Serum chloride measurement, Serum bicarbonate measurement, Serum calcium measurement, Serum magnesium measurement, Serum phosphate measurement, Serum albumin measurement, Serum total protein measurement, Serum bilirubin measurement, Serum alkaline phosphatase measurement, Serum aspartate aminotransferase measurement, Serum alanine aminotransferase measurement, Serum lactate dehydrogenase measurement, Serum uric acid measurement, Serum cholesterol measurement, Serum triglycerides measurement, Serum high-density lipoprotein measurement, Serum low-density lipoprotein measurement
```

References:
- OMOP Common Data Model documentation: https://www.ohdsi.org/data-standardization/the-common-data-model/
